user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskFindIdBySystemData:
```c
int32 OS_TaskFindIdBySystemData(osal_id_t *task_id, const void *sysdata, size_t sysdata_size)
{
    int32             return_code;
    OS_object_token_t token;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(task_id);

    /* The "sysdata" and "sysdata_size" must be passed to the underlying impl for validation */
    return_code = OS_TaskValidateSystemData_Impl(sysdata, sysdata_size);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, OS_TaskIdMatchSystemData_Impl,
                                         (void *)sysdata, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        *task_id = OS_ObjectIdFromToken(&token);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TaskFindIdBySystemData:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
int32 OS_TaskValidateSystemData_Impl(const void *sysdata, size_t sysdata_size)
{
    if (sysdata == NULL || sysdata_size != sizeof(pthread_t))
    {
        return OS_INVALID_POINTER;
    }
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t MatchFunc, void *arg,
                             OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdFindNextMatch(MatchFunc, arg, token);

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "lock_mode" parameter.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }
    else
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
bool OS_TaskIdMatchSystemData_Impl(void *ref, const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_common_record_t *obj)
{
    const pthread_t *               target = (const pthread_t *)ref;
    OS_impl_task_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_task_table, *token);

    return (pthread_equal(*target, impl->id) != 0);
}
...
static inline osal_id_t OS_ObjectIdFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_id;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No function parameter variables are reassigned or otherwise modified in the provided code. Summary of checks performed:
- OS_TaskFindIdBySystemData: parameters are task_id (pointer), sysdata (const void *), and sysdata_size. The code does not assign to any of these parameter variables. The statement "*task_id = OS_ObjectIdFromToken(&token);" modifies the object pointed to by task_id (allowed by Rule 17.8). The cast (void *)sysdata when calling OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch does not modify the parameter variable sysdata itself.
- OS_TaskValidateSystemData_Impl: takes const void *sysdata and size; it only reads these parameters and returns a status; no reassignment of parameters.
- OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch: parameters (lock_mode, idtype, MatchFunc, arg, token) are passed through to helper functions but are not reassigned in the body.
- OS_TaskIdMatchSystemData_Impl: receives void *ref and const token/obj pointers; it casts ref to a const pthread_t * and reads through it, but does not modify the ref parameter variable.
- OS_ObjectIdFromToken and OS_ObjectIdRelease: neither reassign their parameter variables (they access or pass the token pointer but do not change the pointer variable itself).

Note: Calls to other functions (e.g., OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit/Finish, OS_ObjectIdFindNextMatch) may modify data through pointer parameters (the objects they point to), which is permitted by Rule 17.8. Casting away const (the (void *)sysdata cast) is not a modification of the parameter variable itself; while it may be a concern for const-correctness, it does not violate Rule 17.8 as written.
